author: @goodaman4851

text:
I watched it, its not as horrible as people think. It is emotional, but you will not see any brutal scene like in modern day movies. The boy takes the rifle, goes inside, you hear a shot, and the deed is done. The rest is up to your imagination. So movies of that time werent all that brutal.

Even in John Wick the murder of his dog was depicted more detailed than in old Yeller.

The difference is, in old Yeller, you watch a movie where the whole story is about the bond building between the kid and the dog. And when the dog at the end gets rabbies it becomes so sad. And the onlything the boy could do for that dog was to end it, because there is no healing for rabbies, and the time the movie plays in had no regular vets that would put animals to sleep.

I think it was a very educating movie about life. So there is no reason nowdays to do the same to your own pet, specialy because we got vets for puting them down peacefully.
But the movie is a wonderfull movie about the love between a dog and a kid. And that the kid loved his dog so much that he couldnt stand it suffering.

But i think its a movie for 12+ least, everything bellow that age could have issues to understand the content of the movie properly.

author: @logancollier524

text:
That film is actually a lesson that most people don't want to learn, and avoid learning at all costs. That's why we are where we are in this messed up society, and it's got nothing to do with lack of compassion or empathy....it's got to do with pure weakness, and the lack of realization that to grow up, sometimes you have to make hard decisions, and you have to live with those decisions.
Nowhere has it ever been written that we as a species are bound to live a comfortable life, free of encumbrances that may make us upset, ill of spirit, or generally just feeling shitty about somnething that happened. Your feelings are your own, and you have to own them.
Sometimes life makes us confront things we may not want to see, and this happens often as is demonstrated in the book Old Yeller. 
Life sucks, and then you die. Make the best of it while you're here and try and understand it for what it is.......a temporary trasnsitional learning point.
author: @JohnBaker-vm1wf
